TITLE: Lithium Scarcity Pushes Carmakers Into the Mining Business
SUMMARY: Ford, General Motors and others are striking deals with mining companies to avoid raw material shortages that could thwart their electric vehicle ambitions.

TITLE: ‘American Made’ T-Shirts Are Having Their Best Year Yet
SUMMARY: Flag-themed apparel and other Americana are always July Fourth favorites, but it now may matter more where those stars and stripes were stitched.

TITLE: If You Don’t Have Anything Nice to Say, Don’t Be a Reference
SUMMARY: Sometimes maximum awkwardness is worth it, if it means you can be honest.

TITLE: Musk Says Twitter Is Limiting Number of Posts Users Can Read
SUMMARY: The change on Saturday came as thousands of users complained about getting an error message that they had “exceeded” their “rate limit.”

TITLE: L.A. Workers Are Feeling Emboldened as Unions Pressure Employers in California
SUMMARY: California union members are pressuring employers over wages in one of the nation’s most labor-friendly states.

TITLE: A ‘Cage Match’ Between Elon Musk and Mark Zuckerberg May Be No Joke
SUMMARY: Talks over a matchup between the two tech billionaires have progressed and the parameters of an event are taking shape.

TITLE: Affirmative Action Ruling May Upend Diversity Hiring Policies, Too
SUMMARY: The Supreme Court decision on college admissions could lead companies to alter recruitment and promotion practices to pre-empt legal challenges.

TITLE: Fox News to Pay $12 Million to Settle Ex-Producer Abby Grossberg’s Suit
SUMMARY: The settlement with a former producer, Abby Grossberg, is the latest development in a series of legal battles involving Fox.

TITLE: How Amazon Taught Alexa to Speak in an Irish Brogue
SUMMARY: For Alexa to speak like a Dubliner, Amazon researchers had to crack a problem that’s vexed data scientists for years: voice disentanglement.

TITLE: United’s Passengers Were Stuck, but Its C.E.O. Flew on a Private Plane
SUMMARY: The airline has had to cancel and delay more flights than other carriers after storms and other problems disrupted air travel around the country this week.

TITLE: Hollywood Actors Extend Contract Talks at Deadline
SUMMARY: Their union, SAG-AFTRA, and the major studios pushed the expiration date ahead to July 12 and will keep negotiating.

TITLE: At the Front Lines of the Inflation Fight, Uncertainty Reigns
SUMMARY: Central bankers and economists gathered this week and, amid concerns about persistent inflation, wondered about all the things they still don’t know.

TITLE: C.E.O.s of Google, Hertz, Peloton and Live Nation Were Highest Paid Last Year
SUMMARY: C.E.O. pay has risen again, reaching levels that were unthinkable a generation ago. Google, Hertz, Peloton and Live Nation lead the list.

TITLE: Fireworks Have a New Competitor: Drones
SUMMARY: The light displays are quieter, safer and better for the environment.

TITLE: Does It Help to Know How Much the Boss Makes?
SUMMARY: Sky-high C.E.O. pay isn’t a secret. And transparency about those big numbers can have surprising effects on the work force as a whole.

TITLE: American Cities Have a Conversion Problem, and It’s Not Just Offices
SUMMARY: Piles of regulations, or “kludge,” and a culture of “no” are limiting the ability to turn building blocks into something new.

TITLE: TikTok Sells A Lot of Books. Now, Its Owner Wants to Publish Them, Too.
SUMMARY: As ByteDance launches a publishing company, many in the book world wonder if it will create an uneven playing field by boosting its own authors at the expense of others.

TITLE: David Gilmour, Who Turned a Tiny Island Into a Resort, Dies at 91
SUMMARY: An entrepreneur for more than 50 years, he built a luxurious club in Fiji and started a bottled water company, now the second-largest imported water brand in the United States.

TITLE: Joseph Pedott, 91, Dies; Made Chia Pets an ‘as Seen on TV’ Sensation
SUMMARY: The commercials he created, with their “ch-ch-ch-Chia” jingle, became as much a vivid part of American consumer life as the goofy product they sold.

TITLE: Many Student Loan Borrowers Will Continue to Struggle After Supreme Court Ruling
SUMMARY: Those who didn’t complete their degrees and many parents are among the borrowers likely to face challenging times ahead.

TITLE: What Will Happen to Your Student Loans Now
SUMMARY: The pandemic pause on student loan payments will end soon, but a new system for calculating repayments may lower monthly bills.

TITLE: Don’t Use A.I. to Cheat in School. It’s Better for Studying.
SUMMARY: Generative A.I. tools can annotate long documents, make flashcards, and produce practice quizzes.

TITLE: The Ways You Can Still Cancel Your Student Debt
SUMMARY: The Supreme Court’s decision on student loan cancellation does not change programs that help public servants and low-income or disabled borrowers.

TITLE: Ms. Rachel the YouTube Star Wants to Sing With Her Littles
SUMMARY: The YouTube star of “Songs for Littles,” an online video series that pulls millions of views, says she’s found her calling in encouraging children to speak.

TITLE: Retiree Medical Costs Expected to Stay Flat in 2023
SUMMARY: An estimate puts the average cost over a 20-year retirement at about $157,000. That’s almost double the estimate in 2002.

TITLE: Key Inflation Gauge Cooled in May, Welcome News for Federal Reserve
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve is watching to see how much the economy is slowing as it tries to wrangle inflation. Fresh data offered hopeful hints.

TITLE: Consumer Spending Stalled Last Month
SUMMARY: The slowdown is good news for policymakers worried about inflation, but a sign that the engine of the economy could be losing steam.

TITLE: Corporate Diversity Policies Face Threats After Supreme Court Ruling
SUMMARY: Many businesses have adopted policies to diversify hiring but the Supreme Court’s ruling to end the policy in universities endangers those efforts.

TITLE: Eurozone Inflation Slows, but Underlying Price Pressures Persist
SUMMARY: The annual rate of inflation fell to 5.5 percent in June, compared with 6.1 percent the month before. But “core” inflation edged higher.

TITLE: Florida Tourism Rolls On Despite Travel Advisories and Political Battles
SUMMARY: Even as civil rights groups suggest travelers should rethink trips to the state because of policies enacted by its Republican lawmakers, it remains a tourism juggernaut. And some visitors say their spending actually supports opposition to the new laws.

TITLE: Stock Markets Close Upbeat First Half, but Worries Linger
SUMMARY: As companies begin to report earnings and make forecasts, investors are looking for signs of resilience, while executives are playing cautious.

TITLE: A French Newsroom on Strike After Appointment of ‘Far-Right’ Editor
SUMMARY: Journalists at a leading newspaper, Le Journal du Dimanche, have walked out over fears that Geoffroy Lejeune will turn it into a right-wing platform.

TITLE: Libor Is Coming to an End
SUMMARY: It has been an arduous process to get the financial system to stop relying on the tarnished interest-rate benchmark.

TITLE: Dylan Mulvaney Speaks Out After Backlash Against Bud Light
SUMMARY: Dylan Mulvaney has faced stalking and personal attacks since featuring Bud Light on her social media in April, she said, adding that the beer maker did not contact her in light of the hostility.

TITLE: Supreme Court Sides With Postal Carrier Who Refused to Work on Sabbath
SUMMARY: The unanimous decision interpreted a federal civil rights law to require employers to make substantial efforts to accommodate their workers’ religious practices.

TITLE: National Geographic Lays Off More Writers
SUMMARY: The company did not specify how many were shed and said that the magazine, known for its focus on discovery and exploration, would continue to be published on a monthly basis.

TITLE: Volkswagen Replaces Audi Chief Amid Pressure to Electrify
SUMMARY: Gernot Döllner, who is considered close to Volkswagen’s chief, Oliver Blume, will take over at Audi starting Sept. 1.

TITLE: Europe’s Inflation Issue Moves Into a New Phase: From Profits to Wages
SUMMARY: The European Central Bank expects to bring down inflation, with a big caveat: Companies need to let profits fall as they pay for higher wages.

TITLE: Shein Flew Influencers to China to Help Its Image. A Backlash Ensued.
SUMMARY: The fast-fashion company’s attempt to rebut allegations of forced labor and poor working conditions was met with incredulity online.

TITLE: GDP Data Shows US Economic Growth Rate of 2% in Q1
SUMMARY: Government data showed that G.D.P. rose at a 2 percent rate in the first quarter, better than initially reported.

TITLE: Opposition Grows to U.S. Imports of ‘Laundered’ Russian Oil
SUMMARY: Human rights groups and Ukrainian officials want the United States to stop buying Russian crude oil that has been refined into other products in third countries like India

TITLE: Three Charged With Illegally Trading Ahead of Trump Media Merger
SUMMARY: The arrests came after an investigation into trading in the securities of Digital World Acquisition Group, which merged with former President Donald Trump’s social media platform.

TITLE: Behind RFK Jr.’s Popularity With Tech Elites Like Jack Dorsey
SUMMARY: Robert Kennedy Jr.’s contentious claims on issue including vaccines are drawing acclaim from tech executives who are giving him money and exposure.

TITLE: Fed Chair Powell Says He Expects Slower Interest Rate Increases to Continue
SUMMARY: After rapid interest rate increases, Federal Reserve officials could move to a steadily slower pace — though they are not ready to commit.

TITLE: Cheaper Than Water? Retailers Try to Unload Bud Light.
SUMMARY: The brand is still struggling to win back customers. Nowhere is that more apparent than at stores, where cases of the beer sit untouched.

TITLE: Twitter’s New CEO, Linda Yaccarino, Eases Into the Hot Seat
SUMMARY: Linda Yaccarino, who initially could not take ad sales meetings because of a noncompete clause, is adjusting to her new role reporting to Elon Musk.

TITLE: Ryan Seacrest, “Wheel of Fortune” and the Lasting Pull of Game Shows
SUMMARY: “Wheel of Fortune,” “Jeopardy!” and “Family Feud” continue to attract big audiences even as streaming upends viewing habits.

TITLE: Help! A British Travel Agency Has Our $3,891 and We Want It Back.
SUMMARY: A couple’s efforts to use credit to book a new European trip was stymied by questionable customer service, until our columnist stepped in.

TITLE: Chris Printup, Founder of Streetwear Brand Born X Raised, Dies at 42
SUMMARY: Mr. Printup, known as “Spanto,” died on Wednesday morning in Albuquerque, N.M., from injuries sustained in a car accident on Sunday, the brand confirmed.

TITLE: Costco Is Cracking Down on Membership Sharing
SUMMARY: The wholesale retailer announced on Wednesday that it will require identification at all registers, including self-checkout lanes, eliminating a popular shopping secret.

TITLE: Microsoft and Activision Chiefs Testify Merger Will Benefit Consumers
SUMMARY: In federal court, Satya Nadella and Bobby Kotick opposed an attempt by the F.T.C. to delay Microsoft’s $70 billion acquisition of a video game giant.

TITLE: Auto-Industry Group Assails Biden’s Plan to Electrify America’s Cars
SUMMARY: The E.P.A.’s plan is “neither reasonable nor achievable,” the lobbying group said, using strong language in the face of the urgency to cut planet-warming emissions from vehicles.

TITLE: Fourth of July Travel: What to Expect This Weekend
SUMMARY: Delays and cancellations have hit airports in the Northeast, just in time for the July 4 holiday. Airlines and regulators are bickering about who is to blame. Here’s what you need to know.

TITLE: Stress Tests Show Largest Banks Are Sturdy, Fed Says
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve tested banks’ ability to endure a real estate crash, high unemployment and trading turmoil.

TITLE: Overstock to Rebrand as Bed Bath & Beyond
SUMMARY: The online retailer is renaming its website and its mobile app after buying the intellectual property of the bankrupt home-goods store.

TITLE: Top Central Bankers Expect More Rate Increases Amid Stubborn Inflation
SUMMARY: The heads of the Federal Reserve, European Central Bank and Bank of England said that while inflation was moderating somewhat there was still more work to be done.

TITLE: Biden Administration Weighs Further Curbs on Sales of A.I. Chips to China
SUMMARY: Reports that the White House may clamp down on sales of semiconductors that power artificial intelligence capabilities sent tech stocks diving.
